bibl.title: Letter from W.F. Arnold to Howard A. Kelly, October 14, 1907

div1.p: Arnold defends the reputation of Ross.

div1.head: Letter from W.F. Arnold to Howard A. Kelly, October 14, 1907
div1.opener:
V
not ans.
W. F. ARNOLD, M.D.
Hotel Stafford, City,
October fourteenth, MVMVII.
(Dictated.)
Prof. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
City,
Dear Prof. Kelly:
div1.p:
To-night in your address at the Johns Hopkins Hospital
History Club you mentioned unfavorably by name and as obstructionists to
the late Dr. James Carroll's work only two persons, to-wit: Dr. John
Guiteras and “Major” Ross, the comdg. officer of the Las Animas Hospital.

With the former, I have no concern; but Dr. John W. Ross, then Surgeon
and Lt.-Comdr. U. S. Navy, Retired, I feel quite sure is quite undeser-
ving - even if we admit that he did in the instance you quoted interfere
as you stated that he did - of this invidious distinction.

Judging Guided by my memory alone, I can be sufficiently positive to
assert that Dr. Ross was there merely because he was a yellow fever im-
mune and because in his own and Dr. W. C. Gorgas's opinion, he could be
of service in the yellow fever epidemic that everyone without exception
expected to devastate Americans in Cuba. An older brother of his had died
of it in Havana years before while a consular clerk there; but Ross had
acquired immunity through a severe attack of yellow fever at Grenada, Mis-
sissippi, whither he went as a volunteer very soon after he had entered
the Navy Medical Corps. He served there most gallantly both before and
after the attack mentioned, as you doubtless can learn, along with many
enconiums upon the man's lovable personal attributes, from Dr. Carroll's
nurse whom you quoted to-night. For this service, he was rewarded by
Congress by advancement in his grade; but he did not accept the full
measure of the distinction offered him, and are elected instead merely to
regain the place whichence a new construction of Navy laws had, as he felt,
degraded him. Personally, I do not know another man that would have done
this. Recently, he was promoted to the rank of Medical Director along
with Col. Gorgas's advancement to this rank, the grades being correlative.

Being a much older man than any of those that I have mentioned, I be-
lieve, he had not their advantages; hence, he cannot be called a modern
doctor. But he is a man of an open mind, and he is quite as incapable
as anyone that I know of feeling, much the less of exhibiting, jealousy
towards any colleague or obstructing his work. As an evidence of his in-
dustry, I shall cite the fact that when he was stationed on a Navy supply
ship in Callao, Peru, he secured by passing the rigid examinations (such
as the jealous and unprogressive South Americans submit all in-comers to)
of the University of Lima; and it was admitted throughout the Navy that
he not only did a most unusual amount of good work there, but it was e-
qually well known that he exacted almost no pecuniary profit for himself
from it. Similarly, in the many years that he spent at Pensacola, Flor-
ida, he was the best known medical man probably along the entire Gulf
Coast; and I happen to know that he spent more on his patients than they
paid, at least in money, to him. - Hence, I hope you will consent to ex-
clude the unfavorable reference to him from your paper, or, at least, pub-
lish the incident in full, as it doubtless may be secured in its entirety.
I have the honor to be, Sir,
